93828: If a workman is to be regularized and is not regularized due to serious allegations of misconduct, the workman cannot be denied the right of regularization without a domestic enquiry.
Termination based on serious allegations of misconduct carries a stigma and affects the character or reputation of the employee.
The plea of loss of confidence in an employee equates to a stigma, which must be handled with due process.
In the absence of a formal domestic inquiry, an employer's action based on loss of confidence or allegations of misconduct may be deemed unlawful.
The Supreme Court's established view is that employees who have been wrongfully terminated are entitled to reinstatement and back wages as per previous judgments.
The court may allow time for the implementation of its orders for reinstatement, while also permitting the employer to conduct a domestic enquiry if desired.
1902038: Writ petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution are maintainable when fundamental rights are implicated, particularly when the actions of the government threaten the freedom of the press as guaranteed under Article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution.
The right to freedom of speech and expression, which includes the freedom of the press, is a fundamental right protected under Article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution.
Restrictions on this freedom must be justified under Article 19(2) and cannot be excessive or arbitrary, reflecting the need for a balance between government regulation and individual rights.

The Union of India is bound by the doctrine of promissory estoppel and cannot retract permissions and assurances given by a prior government, particularly when the petitioners acted upon such assurances in good faith.

The actions taken by the Lieutenant Governor of Delhi, including the issuance of notices for re-entry and demolition, were found to be arbitrary and politically motivated, violating the principles of natural justice and the rule of law.

The Lieutenant Governor does not possess the same powers as the Chief Commissioner with respect to the administration of properties of the Union, and any attempt to assert such powers without proper authorization is invalid.
Compliance with Zoning Laws and Lease Terms
The construction undertaken by the Express Newspapers Pvt. Ltd. was in compliance with the terms of the lease and the applicable zoning laws, including the approved Floor Area Ratio (FAR) of 360.
Compliance with Zoning Laws and Lease Terms
The notices issued for alleged breaches of the lease terms were found to be unfounded and lacked a factual basis.

Judicial review is applicable even in cases involving contractual issues where statutory provisions of public law are involved, enabling courts to strike down executive actions that are arbitrary or irrational.
1761200: Liability of Insurance Companies for Gratuitous Passengers
Under the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988, an insurance policy covering third-party risk is not required to exclude gratuitous passengers in a vehicle, irrespective of the vehicle's type or class.
Liability of Insurance Companies for Gratuitous Passengers

The deletion of clause (ii) from the proviso of Section 95(1)(b) of the old Act, which pertained to passenger liability, is critical in establishing the insurance company's liability for gratuitous passengers.
Differences Between Old and New Acts
The definitions of 'goods vehicle' under the old Act and 'goods carriage' under the new Act differ significantly, with the new Act explicitly excluding the carriage of passengers.
Differences Between Old and New Acts

The new Act's Section 149(2) limits the defences available to insurers, particularly regarding the liability for passengers carried in goods vehicles, which impacts the insurer's obligation to pay compensation.
The case clarifies the interpretation of the new Act in relation to the liability of insurance companies, thus serving as a reference point for subsequent judgments concerning similar issues.
The ruling prompts the need for a larger bench to reconsider previous decisions, highlighting the evolving legal landscape regarding insurance liability and passenger coverage.
The modifications in the Motor Vehicles Act, particularly the removal of certain clauses, signify a legislative intent to redefine liability and clarify the coverage of insurance policies.
The changes in the definitions and insurance requirements indicate a shift towards stricter liability for insurers regarding accidents involving gratuitous passengers.
1271338: The absence of independent witnesses in a case does not automatically invalidate the prosecution's case, as the behavior of witnesses in serious crimes can be unpredictable and may not conform to expected norms.
The court should examine the overall credibility of the prosecution's version while accounting for the context of the incident and the nature of witness reactions.

Minor contradictions in a witness's testimony should not lead to the rejection of their entire account, especially if the witness is a victim and thus in a strong position to provide credible evidence.
Discrepancies that do not undermine the fundamental aspects of the prosecution's case can be overlooked, and courts must consider the normal human errors in perception and memory.

The Supreme Court will not reopen concurrent findings of fact made by lower courts unless it can be established that such findings are based on no evidence, are perverse, or rely on inadmissible evidence.
The special leave to appeal does not grant the parties the right to contest all findings of fact or present every argument that could have been raised in lower courts.
Dying declarations can be considered credible evidence, particularly when they clearly identify the accused and align with other corroborative testimonies.
In cases where there are discrepancies in the statements, the court should evaluate whether these affect the core of the prosecution’s case or merely reflect minor lapses.
1761133: Conviction Based on Uncorroborated Testimony of Trap Witness
A court may act upon the uncorroborated testimony of a trap witness if satisfied that the witness is truthful based on the circumstances of the case.
Conviction Based on Uncorroborated Testimony of Trap Witness
The court may refuse to act on uncorroborated testimony if it finds the witness's credibility questionable.
The conduct of an accused person when confronted by a police officer is admissible under Section 8 of the Evidence Act.
Statements made to a police officer during the course of investigation are excluded by Section 162 of the Criminal Procedure Code, but conduct that does not amount to a statement is admissible.
The immediate reaction of the accused upon being questioned can corroborate the testimony of the trap witness.
Circumstances surrounding the accused's actions, such as possession of the bribe and the manner in which he handled the file, serve as corroborating evidence.
There is a clear distinction between the admissibility of conduct and statements made during police investigations, with conduct being admissible as evidence if relevant to the case.
1274317: Burden of Proof for Continuous Service
The claimant bears the initial burden of proving that they have worked for 240 days in the year preceding their termination, and this burden requires cogent evidence, both oral and documentary.
Burden of Proof for Continuous Service
Affidavits or self-serving statements from the claimant are insufficient to discharge this burden, and the claimant must present concrete evidence such as muster rolls or payment records.
Adverse Inference for Non-Production of Evidence

The failure of the management to produce relevant documents, such as nominal muster rolls, may lead to an adverse inference against them, but the claimant must still establish their case based on the evidence they provide.
Adverse Inference for Non-Production of Evidence
Mere non-production of muster rolls without a specific plea of suppression by the claimant does not automatically warrant an adverse inference against the management.
Definition of 'Workman' Under Industrial Disputes Act
The definition of 'workman' under the Industrial Disputes Act is inclusive, and employees working in government departments can qualify as workmen, thus entitled to protections under the Act.
Definition of 'Workman' Under Industrial Disputes Act
The classification of a department as an 'industry' under the Act is subject to judicial interpretation and must align with precedents set by higher courts.
Concurrent Findings of Fact
The High Court should not interfere with the concurrent findings of fact established by the labor court unless those findings are shown to be perverse or irrational.
Concurrent Findings of Fact
Judicial review does not extend to reevaluating factual determinations made by lower courts if the findings are supported by evidence.
Certifications and Records Maintenance
Governments should implement better record-keeping practices for daily wage earners to reduce disputes regarding employment duration and to provide clearer documentation of service.
Certifications and Records Maintenance
Certificates issued by designated authorities confirming the number of days worked can help mitigate litigations and clarify the status of employment for daily wage workers.
442524: Interim Ex Parte Injunction Standards
The court has the authority to issue interim ex parte injunctions to prevent harm or injury to a party's rights until a final decision is made in a suit.
Interim Ex Parte Injunction Standards

Orders for interim injunctions must comply with the procedural requirements outlined in the relevant rules, including giving notice to the opposing party unless there is a clear and documented reason for not doing so.
Consequences of Non-Compliance with Procedural Requirements
Failure to adhere to the procedural requirements for issuing ex parte injunctions can render such orders unsustainable, as parties must be given an opportunity to present their case.
Consequences of Non-Compliance with Procedural Requirements
A party that benefits from an ex parte order but fails to comply with the associated requirements carries the risk of losing that advantage if challenged.
Time Limit for Finalizing Injunction Applications

The court is mandated to endeavor to resolve applications for injunction within thirty days if an injunction is granted without notice to the opposing party, and must document reasons for any failure to do so.
Time Limit for Finalizing Injunction Applications
If the court does not finalize an injunction application within this timeframe, the order may be deemed ineffective, granting the aggrieved party the right to appeal.
Availability of Alternative Remedies
Parties affected by interim orders are encouraged to utilize available statutory remedies, such as motions to vacate the order or appeals against it, before seeking constitutional remedies.
Availability of Alternative Remedies
The High Court’s constitutional jurisdiction should not replace the pursuit of statutory remedies unless absolutely necessary.
Impact of Judicial Inaction
Judicial inaction in adhering to procedural mandates may entitle affected parties to appeal against provisional orders, regardless of ongoing applications for injunction.
Impact of Judicial Inaction

An appeal can address both the merits of the injunction and the procedural failures of the lower court, and the appellate court has the discretion to recommend actions against the erring judicial officer.
769322: The communication by the court to the parties or their counsel regarding the filing of an award is considered sufficient compliance with the requirement of notice under the Arbitration Act.
Notice does not necessarily require written communication; oral communication is adequate when no specific mode of service is prescribed.

The period of limitation for filing objections to an arbitration award begins from the date the court adjourns the matter for parties' say on the award, regardless of whether formal written notice is issued.
A party's knowledge of the filing of the award, whether through formal or informal means, constitutes sufficient notice for the commencement of the limitation period.
Appealability of Orders Refusing to Set Aside Awards
An order of the court that does not involve an objection for setting aside an award cannot be interpreted as a refusal to set aside the award, thus making it non-appealable under the Arbitration Act.
Appealability of Orders Refusing to Set Aside Awards
No appeal lies when no objections have been formally raised before the court regarding the setting aside of the award.
If an objection to an arbitration award is not pressed before the trial court, it is presumed to be abandoned and cannot be raised later in appeal.
1281050: Violation of Eligibility Criteria

The acceptance of the tender from the fourth respondents, who did not meet the eligibility criteria of being a registered second-class hotelier with at least five years of experience, was deemed invalid as it contravened the standards set forth in the tender notice.
Violation of Eligibility Criteria
The first respondent was required to adhere to the prescribed eligibility criteria, and the failure to do so constituted arbitrary action, violating the principles of equality under the Constitution.
Arbitrariness in State Action
The principle of non-arbitrariness mandates that state actions, particularly in awarding contracts, must conform to rational and non-discriminatory standards.
Arbitrariness in State Action
Any deviation from established norms without justifiable reasoning is subject to judicial scrutiny and can be invalidated.
Instrumentality of the State

The International Airport Authority of India was classified as an instrumentality of the State under Article 12 of the Constitution, binding it to the same constitutional and administrative law limitations as the government.
Instrumentality of the State
This classification entails that the authority must act within the bounds of reasonableness and fairness in its dealings, particularly in matters concerning public tenders.
Equal Opportunity in Public Contracts
The acceptance of tenders must ensure equal opportunity for all eligible bidders; any discriminatory practice that excludes similarly situated individuals is unconstitutional.
Equal Opportunity in Public Contracts
The appellant's claim of being denied an equal opportunity to tender was validated, emphasizing the importance of equitable treatment in public procurement.
Judicial Review of Government Discretion
Judicial review is applicable to government actions related to public contracts to ensure that decisions are not made arbitrarily or capriciously.
Judicial Review of Government Discretion
The government must provide adequate justification when deviating from established eligibility criteria or tender norms.
Legal Protection of Government Contracts
Legal entitlements derived from government contracts, although often viewed as privileges, are subject to legal protections to prevent arbitrary denial by the government.
Legal Protection of Government Contracts
Procedural safeguards must be in place to ensure that government discretion in awarding contracts is not exercised in an arbitrary manner.
38360473: Ambit and Scope of Section 9A CPC

The case addressed the interpretation of Section 9A of the Code of Civil Procedure, as amended by the Maharashtra Amendment Act, focusing on its applicability concerning objections to the jurisdiction of the court.
Ambit and Scope of Section 9A CPC
Section 9A mandates that issues regarding the jurisdiction of the court should be determined as preliminary issues at the hearing of any application for interim relief.
Jurisdiction and Limitation
The court determined that the issue of limitation is intertwined with the jurisdiction of the court, and thus a plea of limitation can be raised as a jurisdictional issue under Section 9A.
Jurisdiction and Limitation
The ruling established that a suit barred by limitation cannot be entertained by the court, as lack of jurisdiction due to limitation precludes the court from adjudicating the matter.
Relationship Between Section 9A and Order XIV Rule 2
The decision clarified that Section 9A provides a self-contained scheme that operates distinctly from Order XIV Rule 2, which deals with the framing of preliminary issues.
Relationship Between Section 9A and Order XIV Rule 2
The court emphasized that Section 9A's provisions are mandatory and that jurisdictional objections, including those related to limitation, must be resolved before proceeding with the suit.
Precedent on Limitation as a Jurisdictional Issue
The judgment affirmed earlier case law establishing that limitation is a question of law that affects the jurisdiction of the court and must be addressed at the outset of proceedings.
Precedent on Limitation as a Jurisdictional Issue
This ruling reinforced that a finding on limitation directly impacts the court's authority to hear cases, thus establishing a precedent for future adjudications regarding jurisdiction and limitation.
Legislative Intent of Section 9A
The court interpreted the legislative intent behind Section 9A as aiming to prevent abuse of process by ensuring that jurisdictional issues are resolved promptly.
Legislative Intent of Section 9A
The insertion of Section 9A was intended to curtail practices where suits were entertained without a valid jurisdictional basis, thus promoting judicial efficiency.
1442974: Acceptance of Compromise in Personal Disputes
The Court emphasized that in disputes of a purely personal nature, it is advisable to accept the terms of compromise in criminal proceedings.
Acceptance of Compromise in Personal Disputes
Prolonging proceedings without the possibility of a conviction is not a judicious use of judicial resources.
Distinction Between Compounding Offences and Quashing Proceedings
The judgment clarifies that compounding of an offence is distinct from quashing of proceedings, and the threshold for compounding does not necessarily apply to quashing.
Distinction Between Compounding Offences and Quashing Proceedings
The Court noted that the dismissal of the application based on the compounding limit of Rs.250/- was an irrelevant factor in the context of quashing.
Impact of Complainant's Passing on Proceedings
The Court recognized that the death of the complainant substantially impacts the likelihood of a conviction, necessitating a reevaluation of the continuation of proceedings.
The judgment underscores the importance of judicial economy, suggesting that time saved from quashing unnecessary proceedings could be better utilized for more significant cases.
1827392: A deed of relinquishment by a partner is not required to be registered under the Registration Act if it does not convey immovable property but merely records the end of the partnership.
The interest of a partner in partnership assets, including both movable and immovable property, is considered movable property for registration purposes.
Nature of Partner's Interest in Partnership
A partner's interest in partnership assets is treated as a right to receive profits during the partnership and a monetary value of the share in net partnership assets upon dissolution.
Nature of Partner's Interest in Partnership
No partner can claim ownership of specific items of partnership property; rather, their rights are to the profits generated and a share of the value of assets after liabilities are settled.
Unregistered documents relating to the relinquishment of a partner's share in a partnership are admissible in evidence, even in cases where the partnership owns immovable property.
Such documents do not constitute transfers of interest in land but rather record adjustments related to the partnership's business.
Upon dissolution of a partnership, the assets must be liquidated, and the proceeds are to be distributed among partners according to their shares, after settling all debts and liabilities.
The concept of partnership entails that all property brought in by partners loses individual ownership status and becomes partnership property.
167068104: Requirements for Conviction Based on Circumstantial Evidence

In cases relying on circumstantial evidence, the prosecution must establish its case beyond reasonable doubt, ensuring that all circumstances are conclusive and exclude any reasonable hypotheses consistent with the innocence of the accused.
Requirements for Conviction Based on Circumstantial Evidence
The chain of circumstantial evidence must be complete and should convincingly point towards the guilt of the accused.
Discretion in Witness Examination
The prosecution is not obligated to examine all listed witnesses; it is within the discretion of the public prosecutor to determine which witnesses are necessary for proving the prosecution's case.
Discretion in Witness Examination
Absence of certain witnesses may not be fatal to the prosecution's case, provided the overall evidence remains persuasive.
Evaluation of Evidence by Quality, Not Quantity
The legal principle emphasizes weighing the quality of evidence rather than counting the number of witnesses, as a single credible witness can suffice to establish a fact.
Evaluation of Evidence by Quality, Not Quantity
The court is tasked with determining the reliability, credibility, and trustworthiness of the evidence presented.
Minor Discrepancies in Witness Testimony
Minor discrepancies that do not affect the core of the prosecution's case should not lead to the rejection of the evidence as a whole.
Minor Discrepancies in Witness Testimony
The evidence must be evaluated in its entirety, focusing on the overall impression it leaves rather than isolated inconsistencies.
Hostile Witness Testimony
The testimony of a hostile witness cannot be dismissed entirely; it may still hold value if found credible and consistent with either party's case.
Hostile Witness Testimony
The court is permitted to rely on portions of the testimony that are consistent with the prosecution's or the defense's version.
Last Seen Together Doctrine
When an accused is last seen with the victim prior to the crime, it becomes incumbent upon the accused to provide an explanation for the circumstances leading to the victim's death.
Last Seen Together Doctrine
Failure to offer a satisfactory explanation can lead to a strong presumption of guilt.
Motive in Circumstantial Evidence Cases
In circumstantial evidence cases, the existence of motive may be a relevant factor, as it helps to establish the accused's intent and opportunity to commit the crime.
Motive in Circumstantial Evidence Cases
Evidence suggesting a motive can strengthen the prosecution's case.
Obligation of the Accused to Explain Circumstances

Under Section 313 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, the accused must explain incriminating circumstances that are put to him, which may serve as a missing link in the chain of circumstantial evidence.
Obligation of the Accused to Explain Circumstances
A false or unsatisfactory explanation can contribute to the prosecution's case against the accused.
1777887: Nature of Clause 9 in the Memorandum of Understanding
Clause 9 of the Memorandum of Understanding is not an arbitration agreement, but rather a provision for expert determination meant to facilitate the implementation of the agreement.
Nature of Clause 9 in the Memorandum of Understanding
The decision of the Chairman, IFCI, under Clause 9 does not constitute an arbitration award as it does not involve a judicial determination based on evidence presented by the parties.
Distinction Between Arbitration and Expert Determination

An arbitration agreement contemplates binding decisions made by a tribunal with the authority derived from the parties' consent, whereas expert determination is typically focused on providing a valuation or clarification that does not create enforceable rights.
Distinction Between Arbitration and Expert Determination
The court emphasized the need to examine the true intent of the parties and the nature of the dispute resolution mechanism outlined in the agreement.
Abuse of Process of Court
The court affirmed that litigating the same issues in parallel proceedings constitutes an abuse of the process of court, particularly if the claims are substantially identical.
Abuse of Process of Court
However, a suit challenging the decision as a decision, and not as an award, is maintainable and not considered an abuse of process.
Family Settlements and Their Legal Weight
Family settlements, such as the Memorandum of Understanding in this case, should not be lightly interfered with by the courts, especially when they have been acted upon for an extended period.
Family Settlements and Their Legal Weight
The court noted the importance of honoring the terms of family settlements to avoid further disputes among family members.
Finality of Expert Decisions
The court highlighted that decisions made under expert determination processes are final and binding, provided they adhere to the terms outlined in the agreement.
Finality of Expert Decisions
The nature of the expert's role is to facilitate the execution of the agreement rather than to resolve disputes through judicial means.
1486400: Burden of Proof in Cheque Dishonor Cases

In cases of dishonored cheques under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, the presumption is that the cheque was issued for consideration, and the burden of proof lies on the accused to demonstrate otherwise.
Burden of Proof in Cheque Dishonor Cases
The court must presume, unless proven to the contrary, that the holder of the cheque received it for the discharge of a debt or liability.
The presumption regarding the issuance of a cheque for a debt or liability is rebuttable, but the accused must provide cogent evidence to negate this presumption.
A mere denial or averment in response to a legal notice is insufficient to shift the burden of proof back to the complainant.
The accused must lead substantial evidence to prove that the cheque was not issued for a debt or liability, failing which the initial presumption in favor of the complainant stands.
The absence of evidence from the accused results in the affirmance of the complainant's claims regarding the cheque's issuance.
The judgment emphasizes the importance of correctly interpreting Sections 118 and 139 of the Negotiable Instruments Act in relation to the burden of proof in cheque dishonor cases.
Erroneous judicial interpretations that shift the burden onto the complainant can lead to the misapplication of the law and wrongful acquittals.
1863554: Definition and Scope of 'Act of God'
The expression 'act of God' signifies the operation of natural forces free from human intervention and includes unexpected occurrences of nature such as severe gales, snowstorms, and cyclones.
Definition and Scope of 'Act of God'
An act of God provides no excuse unless it is so unexpected that no reasonable human foresight could anticipate the occurrence, having regard to the prevailing conditions.
Concept of Compensation
The term 'compensation' signifies something given in recompense for loss or injury, suggesting equivalence in value.
Concept of Compensation
Compensation should aim to place the claimant as far as possible in the same financial position as before the accident, but it is not intended to be a windfall.
Assessment of Damages for Personal Injury
The assessment of damages for personal injury is inherently challenging, as it involves quantifying non-pecuniary losses such as pain, suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life.
Assessment of Damages for Personal Injury
Damages should not be punitive against the liable party nor should they profit the claimant; rather, they should be fair and just, reflecting the severity of the injury.
Discretion in Determining 'Just' Compensation
The Tribunal has a duty to determine compensation that is 'just', which involves rational and judicious decision-making rather than arbitrary figures.
Discretion in Determining 'Just' Compensation
What constitutes 'just' compensation is a complex question that depends on the specific facts and circumstances of each case.
Distinction Between Pecuniary and Non-Pecuniary Damages
Pecuniary damages are those that can be calculated in monetary terms and include actual expenses and lost earnings, while non-pecuniary damages are more subjective and relate to intangible losses.
Distinction Between Pecuniary and Non-Pecuniary Damages
The assessment of non-pecuniary damages must consider factors such as the claimant's age, marital status, and the extent of deprivation experienced due to the injury.
Legal Principles Governing Compensation Awards
The compensation awarded must not be inadequate, unreasonable, excessive, or deficient, and should reflect the realities of the claimant's situation post-injury.
Legal Principles Governing Compensation Awards
There is no uniform rule for measuring the value of human life or injuries; each case must be assessed based on its unique facts.
Principles of Precedent
While a decision serves as a precedent, it is the underlying principle that is binding, not the specific factual circumstances of the case.
Principles of Precedent
Judges must carefully ascertain the principles laid down in previous decisions without unnecessarily expanding their scope beyond the needs of the case at hand.
1097490: Definition of 'Police Officer' under Evidence Act
Section 25 of the Evidence Act states that no confession made to a police officer shall be proved against a person accused of any offence.
Definition of 'Police Officer' under Evidence Act
The term 'police officer' is not strictly limited to those in a regular police force but includes individuals invested with substantial police powers for investigating penal offences.
Attributes Required to be Considered a Police Officer
An officer must possess the power to lodge a report under Section 173 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to be classified as a police officer under Section 25 of the Evidence Act.
Attributes Required to be Considered a Police Officer
Investigation powers alone, without the ability to submit a charge-sheet, do not qualify an officer as a police officer.
Role of Officers of the Department of Revenue Intelligence (DRI)

Officers of the DRI, while empowered under Section 53 of the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, do not possess the full attributes of a police officer as defined under Section 25 of the Evidence Act.
Role of Officers of the Department of Revenue Intelligence (DRI)
The officers' role concludes with the disposal of the arrested individual and seized articles, without prosecutorial powers.
Limitations on Confessional Statements
Confessional statements made to DRI officers are not barred by Section 25 of the Evidence Act, as these officers do not fulfill the criteria to be considered police officers.
Limitations on Confessional Statements
The protections offered by Section 25 serve to prevent coercive practices by regular police but do not extend to non-police officers, even if they have certain investigative powers.
Legislative Intent and Interpretation

The legislative intent behind the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act emphasizes stringent control over narcotics while delineating the roles of various officers distinctly from that of police officers.
Legislative Intent and Interpretation
There is a clear distinction in the enforcement powers and responsibilities between officers under the Act and those of traditional police forces.
849843: Nature of Interlocutory Orders
An interlocutory order is one that does not finally dispose of the rights of the parties, but merely addresses some point essential to the progress of the suit or trial.
Nature of Interlocutory Orders
The term 'interlocutory order' is used in its natural sense in the context of the Special Courts Act, distinguishing it from final orders.
Appeal Rights under the Special Courts Act
Section 11(1) of the Special Courts Act provides a right of appeal against any judgment, sentence, or order of a Special Court, except for interlocutory orders.
Appeal Rights under the Special Courts Act
The non-obstante clause in the Act clearly excludes the application of the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure regarding interlocutory orders.
Interpretation of Interlocutory Orders
The interpretation of the term 'interlocutory order' should not be equated with orders that affect substantial rights of the parties.
Interpretation of Interlocutory Orders
An order framing charges is considered an interlocutory order as it does not terminate the proceedings but allows the trial to continue.
Legal Precedents on Interlocutory Orders
Legal precedents indicate that orders affecting the rights of the accused or that adjudicate important aspects of the case cannot be categorized as interlocutory.
Legal Precedents on Interlocutory Orders
The distinction between interlocutory and final orders is crucial, as it guides the application of appeal rights and the scope of judicial review.
Purpose of the Special Courts Act
The Special Courts Act aims for the speedy disposal of cases, which necessitates limiting appeals against interlocutory orders to avoid delays.
Purpose of the Special Courts Act
The legislative intent behind the Act was to ensure efficient judicial proceedings in the context of serious crimes involving public officials.
Judicial Discretion and Fairness
It is presumed that a Special Judge, being a sitting High Court judge, exercises due diligence and applies judicial reasoning when framing charges.
Judicial Discretion and Fairness
The absence of a right to appeal against an interlocutory order does not infringe upon the fairness of the trial, as the Special Court remains subject to Article 136 scrutiny.
987: Assessment based on evidence
The assessment under income tax should not be based on mere suspicion or conjecture but must rely on concrete evidence.
Assessment based on evidence
A finding of fact should be supported by relevant and admissible evidence, and not be arrived at through conjectures or irrelevant material.
Weight of evidentiary standards
The Income-tax Officer must consider all evidence presented by the assessee and should not disregard materials that support the assessee's claims.
Weight of evidentiary standards
If the evidence is not sufficient to support a finding, or is based on irrelevant considerations, the finding can be challenged.
Discrepancies in affidavits
Discrepancies in affidavits must be interpreted in context, and not in isolation, to understand the true position of the facts.
Discrepancies in affidavits
Affidavits should be read as a whole to ascertain the intentions and facts being asserted by the deponent.
Remand for reconsideration
If the appellate body fails to consider all relevant evidence or relies on conjecture, the matter may be remanded for further consideration.
Remand for reconsideration
The appellate authority should give both parties the opportunity to present additional evidence.
Role of Appellate Tribunal
The Appellate Tribunal must evaluate all the evidence before it comprehensively and cannot selectively consider information.
Role of Appellate Tribunal
The conclusions drawn by the Tribunal must be based on the entirety of evidence and should reflect a balanced consideration of all facts.
Finding of fact vs. question of law
A finding of fact can be challenged if it lacks evidence or is perverse, indicating that the Tribunal must act within the bounds of reasonableness.
Finding of fact vs. question of law
The distinction between a question of fact and a question of law is critical in determining the scope of judicial review.
854912: The confessional statements recorded under Section 67 of the NDPS Act are admissible in evidence and can be the basis for conviction if found to be voluntary.
The absence of complaints regarding torture or harassment made by the appellants to the Magistrate indicates the voluntariness of the statements.
Evidence from police witnesses cannot be discarded solely based on their affiliation with the investigating agency; corroboration of their evidence should be sought when possible.
The validity of recovery should not be doubted solely due to the non-examination of independent witnesses if the confessional statements are deemed voluntary.
Compliance with Section 42 of the NDPS Act
Section 42(2) of the NDPS Act is not applicable when empowered Gazetted Officers conduct searches, arrests, and seizures.
Compliance with Section 42 of the NDPS Act
The High Court correctly concluded that the actions of the Gazetted Officer conducting the search did not require compliance with Section 42(2) because it was conducted under Section 41.
Evidence obtained from illegal searches or seizures is not necessarily excluded if the accused fails to demonstrate that they were prejudiced by such actions.
The presence of accused during the seizure process and absence of claims of tampering with evidence upheld the legitimacy of the seizure.
762574: Legislative Competence for Taxation
The imposition of purchase tax on the despatch of manufactured goods outside the State in the course of inter-State trade and commerce is beyond the legislative competence of the State Legislature.
Legislative Competence for Taxation
The Constitution (Forty-sixth Amendment) Act, 1982 clarified that taxation on consignment transfers of goods in the course of inter-State trade is within the exclusive purview of Parliament.
Definition of Taxable Event
The taxable event for the levy of tax under Section 9(1)(b) of the Haryana General Sales Tax Act is the despatch of manufactured goods, not the initial purchase of raw materials.
Definition of Taxable Event
Tax liability arises when goods manufactured from raw materials are despatched outside the State, marking a distinct event separate from the purchase of those materials.
Interpretation of 'Disposal'
The term 'disposes of' in the context of the Act is distinct from 'despatch'; mere despatch of goods to oneself does not constitute disposal under the Act.
Interpretation of 'Disposal'
The High Court held that the notification imposing tax on mere despatch was ultra vires as it incorrectly expanded the scope of the statute.
Ultra Vires Provisions
The retrospective validation of the notification imposing purchase tax on despatches was declared void as it sought to override judicial decisions without altering substantive law.
Ultra Vires Provisions
Any penalty proceedings based on an invalid legislative provision are also rendered void.
Doctrine of Pith and Substance
The doctrine emphasizes that the true nature of a tax, rather than its label, determines the legislative authority over it.
Doctrine of Pith and Substance
Encroachment by State legislation into areas reserved for Parliament must be evaluated on the basis of the actual nature of the tax.
Fiscal Statutes Interpretation
Fiscal laws must be strictly construed, and the implications of tax liabilities cannot be determined by referring to other statutes.
Fiscal Statutes Interpretation
The taxable event must be identified based on the specific provisions of the statute creating the tax liability.
Precedent and Judicial Authority
A decision on an unargued question should not be treated as a precedent, emphasizing the need for substantive legal arguments to establish authority.
Precedent and Judicial Authority
Judgments must be evaluated for what they decisively establish, not for broader implications that may arise.
658394: Motive for Murder
The accused had a motive to murder the victim due to his suspicion of her infidelity, which was substantiated by testimony from her family members.
Motive for Murder
The court rejected the argument that mere suspicion of infidelity does not constitute sufficient motive, asserting that it can provoke extreme reactions in possessive individuals.
Last Seen Together
The prosecution established that the deceased was last seen alive in the company of the accused, which is a significant piece of circumstantial evidence.
Last Seen Together
The court highlighted that while the last-seen circumstance alone is insufficient for a conviction, it becomes incriminating when combined with other supporting evidence.
Nature of Injuries
The medical evidence indicated that the injuries sustained by the victim were ante-mortem and could have resulted in instant death, implying intent to kill.
Nature of Injuries
The gruesome nature of the injuries, particularly to the abdomen, pointed to a deliberate and malicious act rather than accidental harm.
Circumstantial Evidence
The court emphasized that in circumstantial cases, the evidence must cumulatively point to the guilt of the accused, leaving no reasonable doubt of innocence.
Circumstantial Evidence
The circumstances established included the accused's motive, opportunity, and the recovery of the murder weapon, which collectively reinforced the prosecution's case.
Recovery of Evidence
Evidence recovered from the scene, including the murder weapon and the accused's clothing with blood stains, was critical in establishing the link between the accused and the crime.
Recovery of Evidence
The court ruled that even if confessions related to recoveries were deemed inadmissible, the conduct of the accused in leading police to the recovery sites remained relevant.
Absconding as Evidence of Guilt
The accused's actions of fleeing the scene and being found in suspicious circumstances shortly after the incident were interpreted as indicators of guilt.
Absconding as Evidence of Guilt
The court cited previous rulings affirming that evading law enforcement procedures can be considered as evidence of a guilty mindset.
1380511: The testimony of injured witnesses is given significant importance in legal proceedings.
Even if co-accused are acquitted due to exaggerations in testimony, a conviction may still be upheld if evidence against another accused is found to be credible and cogent.
The mere fact that witnesses are related to the deceased does not automatically discredit their testimony.
The court must weigh the evidence pragmatically, considering the possibility that witnesses may not shield the real culprit despite their relationship.
The court must carefully analyze and scrutinize the evidence provided by witnesses, particularly those who may be deemed interested or inimical towards the accused.
Clear, cogent, and credible evidence from such witnesses can serve as a basis for conviction.
A direct correlation between the accused's actions and the injuries inflicted on the victim is critical for establishing guilt.
The recovery of the weapon used in the crime, especially when it is stained with the victim's blood, strengthens the case against the accused.
The nature of injuries claimed by the accused can be critically assessed; superficial injuries may be considered self-inflicted or not significant enough to undermine the prosecution's case.
1575531: Governor's Power to Appoint District Judges

The power of appointment of persons to be District Judges conferred on the Governor is an executive function that must be exercised in consultation with the High Court, as stipulated by Article 233(1) of the Constitution.
Governor's Power to Appoint District Judges
The eligibility for appointment is conditioned by the recommendations of the High Court, and the State Government cannot appoint any person as a District Judge outside this panel.
Requirement for Effective Consultation
Consultation between the Governor and the High Court must not be an empty formality but must be real, full, and effective.
Requirement for Effective Consultation
If the State Government finds it difficult to accept the recommendations of the High Court, it must communicate its views to the High Court to enable a proper exchange of opinions.
Judicial Review Limitations
The advice of the Council of Ministers regarding appointments cannot be subjected to judicial review, as per Article 163(1) of the Constitution.
Judicial Review Limitations
However, the High Court may review whether there has been real and effective consultation before a decision is made to reject the panel of candidates.
Writ of Mandamus
A writ of mandamus is not a right but a discretionary remedy that requires a judicially enforceable right for its issuance.
Writ of Mandamus
The High Court cannot issue a mandamus directing the Governor to act contrary to the Council of Ministers' advice regarding the appointment of District Judges.
Principle of Passing Over in Appointments
The principle of passing over a community or group for appointment is integral to the recruitment process and should be exercised based on the High Court's assessment of candidate suitability.
Principle of Passing Over in Appointments
The State Government misapplied the principle of passing over by unilaterally deciding not to appoint candidates from the panel without consulting the High Court.
Constitutional Obligations of the State and High Court
Both the State Government and the High Court have constitutional obligations to ensure that recruitment processes are fair and in accordance with the rules established for communal representation.
Constitutional Obligations of the State and High Court
The Governor's duty to provide relevant facts to the High Court is essential for effective consultation and decision-making regarding appointments.
735457: Liberal Construction of Tax Incentives
A provision in a taxing statute granting incentives for promoting economic growth and development should be construed liberally.
Liberal Construction of Tax Incentives
The restriction on such benefits must be construed to advance the objective of the section and not to frustrate it.
Interpretation of 'Formation'
The focus of the restriction is on the formation of the undertaking rather than the use of previously used buildings or materials.
Interpretation of 'Formation'
The formation should not be deemed to have occurred solely by the transfer of buildings or machinery previously used in another business.
Criteria for New Undertakings
An undertaking that is genuinely new in form and substance should not be denied benefits due to nominal transfers or leases of previously used buildings or equipment.
Criteria for New Undertakings
The existence of nominal value of transferred assets does not necessarily equate to the formation of a new undertaking via those assets.
Judicial Precedents on Tax Benefits
Previous judicial decisions support the interpretation that nominal transfers of machinery or tools do not disqualify an undertaking from claiming tax benefits.
Judicial Precedents on Tax Benefits
The courts have consistently held that the monetary value of old assets transferred must be substantial enough to affect the determination of new status.
Objective of Legislative Intent
The legislative intent behind the relevant tax provisions is to encourage industrialization and to avoid penalizing genuine new undertakings.
Objective of Legislative Intent
Any interpretation that leads to an unjust denial of benefits to genuine new industrial undertakings contradicts the purpose of the tax provision.
981675: Discrimination Under Article 14

The order transferring the petitioner's assessment proceedings was deemed discriminatory and violated the fundamental right of equality before the law as guaranteed under Article 14 of the Constitution.
Discrimination Under Article 14
The executive order lacked legal support and effectively discriminated against the petitioner by subjecting it to inconvenience and harassment without any justifiable basis.
Ultra Vires Provisions of the Tax Act

Sections 5(7-A) and 64(5)(b) of the Indian Income-Tax Act were held to be ultra vires Article 14 of the Constitution, as they allowed arbitrary and unrestrained powers to the income-tax authorities for case transfers.
Ultra Vires Provisions of the Tax Act
The provisions did not provide necessary safeguards or reasonable restrictions, leading to potential misuse and discrimination against individual assessees.
Natural Justice and Right to Representation

The exercise of the power to transfer assessment cases must conform to the principles of natural justice, implying that affected parties should have the opportunity to be heard before any adverse decision is made.
Natural Justice and Right to Representation
The absence of a hearing or recorded reasons for the transfer order highlighted a lack of adherence to procedural fairness, which is essential in a democratic legal framework.
Assessment Procedure and Rights of Assessees

The Court emphasized that the provisions regarding the place of assessment under Section 64 of the Income-Tax Act are mandatory and confer valuable rights upon the assessees, which cannot be arbitrarily taken away.
Assessment Procedure and Rights of Assessees
Any transfer order must pertain to a specific assessment case and cannot be executed in a blanket manner without regard to the individual circumstances of the assessees.
Judicial Review of Executive Action
The decision reinforced the principle that executive actions affecting fundamental rights are subject to judicial review, ensuring that such actions conform to the rule of law.
Judicial Review of Executive Action
The judiciary's role is to safeguard against arbitrary exercise of power by the executive, especially when it infringes upon the rights of individuals.
342168: Police Atrocities and Human Rights Violations
Police atrocities in India are a subject of controversy; any form of torture or cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment is prohibited under Article 21 of the Constitution.
Police Atrocities and Human Rights Violations
The State is responsible if a person in police custody is deprived of life except as per legal procedures, emphasizing the need for police accountability.
Burden of Proof in Custodial Death Cases
In cases of custodial death, the burden of proof shifts to the accused, particularly if the victim's body cannot be recovered.
Burden of Proof in Custodial Death Cases
The courts must adopt a realistic approach in evaluating evidence due to the unique difficulties in obtaining direct evidence against police personnel.
Legal Standards for Conviction Based on Witness Testimony
Convictions can be based on the testimony of a single, reliable witness, and the quality of evidence is more important than quantity.
Legal Standards for Conviction Based on Witness Testimony
The testimony of an accomplice or a witness who has not been tried can be considered, but it requires careful scrutiny and corroboration.
Suo Motu Enhancement of Sentences
The High Court retains the power to enhance sentences suo motu under Section 386(e) of the Criminal Procedure Code, provided the accused are given an opportunity to be heard.
Suo Motu Enhancement of Sentences
The enhancement of sentences must be justified by the seriousness of the offences and the context of the case.
Reliability of Witness Accounts
The reliability of witnesses can be challenged if discrepancies exist between their pre-trial statements and their courtroom testimonies.
Reliability of Witness Accounts
Witness intimidation and the context of police involvement may affect witness credibility and the overall assessment of evidence.
Impact of Police Conduct on Legal Proceedings
The actions of police officials during investigations, including threats and intimidation of witnesses, can influence the integrity of the judicial process.
Impact of Police Conduct on Legal Proceedings
The courts must take into account the systemic issues of police misconduct when evaluating cases of custodial violence.
Necessity of Evidence Beyond Corpus Delicti
In murder cases, recovery of the victim's body is not a prerequisite for conviction; reliable evidence of death and criminal agency suffices.
Necessity of Evidence Beyond Corpus Delicti
Circumstantial evidence can be utilized to establish the occurrence of a murder when direct evidence is unavailable.
328748: Validity of Preventive Detention while in Custody
Subsisting custody of the detenue does not invalidate an order of preventive detention; the decision must depend on the facts of the particular case.
Validity of Preventive Detention while in Custody
Preventive detention is ordinarily not needed when the detenue is already in custody, unless there is a reasonable basis for anticipating the detenue's release.
Awareness of Detaining Authority
The detaining authority must demonstrate awareness of the fact that the detenue is in custody at the time of making the detention order.
Awareness of Detaining Authority
Failure to indicate the likelihood of the detenue's release on bail, alongside ample material supporting the criminal charge, may render the detention order invalid.
Criteria for Anticipatory Detention

Even if the detenue is in custody, a detention order can be validly made if the detaining authority is reasonably satisfied on cogent material that there is a likelihood of the detenue's release and that antecedent activities justify preventive detention.
Criteria for Anticipatory Detention
The proximity of the antecedent activities in time is crucial for justifying the detention order.
Invalidity of Detention Order
In the case at hand, the detention order was quashed because it was made while the detenue was in jail custody with no prospect of release, failing to meet the test established by previous case law.
Invalidity of Detention Order
This highlights the requirement for the detaining authority to consider the existing custody of the detenue when making a preventive detention order.
Implications of Judicial Precedents

The ruling reinforces the principles established in prior case law regarding preventive detention, particularly those that outline the necessity of considering a detenue's existing incarceration status and the implications for future actions.
Implications of Judicial Precedents
This case serves as a reaffirmation of the legal standards necessary to validate preventive detention orders.
1677837: Constitutionality of Section 5(7A) of the Indian Income-tax Act
Section 5(7A) of the Indian Income-tax Act is constitutionally valid and does not infringe upon the fundamental rights conferred by Articles 14 and 19(1)(g) of the Constitution.
Constitutionality of Section 5(7A) of the Indian Income-tax Act

The section is designed to confer administrative convenience by allowing the transfer of income-tax cases among officers, and its application does not create substantial discrimination against any particular assessee.
Discretionary Power of Authorities

The discretionary power granted to the Commissioner of Income-tax and the Central Board of Revenue under Section 5(7A) is not discriminatory, as it must be exercised within the framework and purpose of the Income-tax Act.
Discretionary Power of Authorities
The exercise of discretion should be assessed on two criteria: whether it allows for real and substantial discrimination and whether it impinges on a fundamental right.
Right to Administrative Convenience

The right conferred on assessees under Sections 64(1) and (2) of the Income-tax Act is not absolute and is subject to the exigencies of tax collection, which may necessitate the transfer of cases for efficient administration.
Right to Administrative Convenience
Discretionary transfers based on administrative convenience do not constitute a deprivation of equal rights before the law.
Principles of Natural Justice in Transfers

While the transfer of cases under Section 5(7A) does not inherently require adherence to principles of natural justice, it is advisable that authorities give notice to affected assessees and record reasons for transfers to avoid perceptions of mala fides or discrimination.
Principles of Natural Justice in Transfers
The absence of notice or reasons can lead to challenges in court if an assessee demonstrates a prima facie case of mala fides.
Validity of Omnibus Transfer Orders

The explanation added to Section 5(7A) by the Amending Act XXVI of 1956 clarifies that omnibus wholesale orders of transfer are valid if they encompass all proceedings related to an assessee, thus addressing concerns raised in prior judgments.
Validity of Omnibus Transfer Orders
Such transfers must be interpreted to include pending cases and those that may arise in the future, ensuring continuity in procedures.
342635: No authority, including a quasi-judicial authority, can confer jurisdiction on itself by incorrectly deciding a jurisdictional fact.
The determination of whether a party is a resident or non-resident is a jurisdictional fact that can be challenged in a writ application.
For an appeal under Section 30(1A) to be maintainable, the appellant must have deducted and paid the tax due from the non-resident as stipulated by the statute.
A party claiming that a payment was made to a non-resident firm cannot comply with the conditions for appeal if they contest the non-resident status.
If the High Court concludes that an Income-tax Officer has wrongly assumed jurisdiction by incorrectly deciding a jurisdictional fact, it is entitled to grant a writ of certiorari.
The issuance of a writ of certiorari is justified to prevent the imposition of a levy based on an erroneous decision regarding jurisdiction.
1664373: Legal Standing of Unregistered Partnership Firms
The suit filed by an unregistered partnership firm against a third party for enforcement of any right arising from a contract is barred under Section 69(2) of the Partnership Act from its inception.
Legal Standing of Unregistered Partnership Firms
For a suit to be barred under Section 69(2), the plaintiff partnership firm must not be registered at the time of filing, and the suit must be for enforcement of rights arising from a contract.
Distinction Between Contractual and Statutory Rights

A suit for possession based on the statutory obligation under Section 108(q) of the Transfer of Property Act does not arise from the erstwhile contract and therefore is not barred under Section 69(2) of the Partnership Act.
Distinction Between Contractual and Statutory Rights
The distinction lies in whether the suit seeks to enforce a right from the expired contract or a statutory right based on the law of the land.
Tenant at Sufferance
An erstwhile tenant who continues in possession after the expiration of the lease is classified as a tenant at sufferance, which does not provide them any independent right to continue possession.
Tenant at Sufferance
The landlord must seek legal recourse to regain possession, as the tenant's continued possession is protected by statutory provisions until a court order is obtained.
Composite Cause of Action

A plaintiff's cause of action can be based on multiple grounds, including both contractual breaches and statutory obligations, and the presence of one valid ground may sustain the suit even if another is barred.
Composite Cause of Action
In this case, the plaintiff's claim for possession was partly based on a breach of covenant and partly on the statutory right to possession under the Transfer of Property Act.
Effect of Subsequent Registration of Partnership
The subsequent registration of a partnership firm does not retroactively cure the defect of an unregistered firm filing a suit under Section 69(2) of the Partnership Act.
Effect of Subsequent Registration of Partnership
However, the validity of the subsequent registration and its implications on the suit may require further judicial examination in different factual contexts.
837708: Jurisdiction of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner
The Appellate Assistant Commissioner has the jurisdiction to reject the method of accounting followed by the assessee and accepted by the Income-tax Officer under certain conditions.
Jurisdiction of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner

Specifically, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner can exercise powers to enhance the assessment if, in his opinion, the income, profits, or gains cannot be properly deduced from the method of accounting.
Interpretation of Proviso to Section 13

The proviso to Section 13 of the Indian Income-tax Act stipulates that the Income-tax Officer must determine whether the method of accounting regularly employed by the assessee allows for a proper deduction of income, profits, and gains.
Interpretation of Proviso to Section 13
This determination is exclusive to the Income-tax Officer and cannot be substituted by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.
Finality of the Income-tax Officer's Determination

The Income-tax Officer's determination regarding the method of accounting is not final if the assessee appeals; however, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner cannot reject the method of accounting unless the Income-tax Officer has expressly done so.
Finality of the Income-tax Officer's Determination

The powers of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner are wide but limited to the subject matter of the appeal and cannot extend to making determinations reserved for the Income-tax Officer under the proviso.
Powers of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner
The Appellate Assistant Commissioner may confirm, reduce, enhance, or annul the assessment based on the evidence presented during the appeal.
Powers of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner
He can also set aside the assessment and direct the Income-tax Officer to make a fresh assessment, but he cannot independently reject the method of accounting.
Case Law References
The judgment references prior case law, including Narrondas Manordass and K. F. Vakeel, establishing principles regarding the jurisdiction and powers of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.
Case Law References

The case highlights the divergence of opinions between different High Courts regarding the interpretation of the powers conferred upon the Appellate Assistant Commissioner versus those reserved for the Income-tax Officer.
1508507: Interpretation of Customs Tariff Items
Item 72(3) of the Indian Customs Tariff specifically covers component parts of machinery, including pot motors, which are essential for the functioning of the machinery.
Interpretation of Customs Tariff Items
Pot motors are designed uniquely for use in rayon spinning machines and cannot be utilized for any other purpose, thereby qualifying them as component parts under Item 72(3).
Specific vs. General Items in Customs Tariff
Item 72(3) is deemed a specific item that applies to pot motors, while Item 73(21), which deals with electric motors, is considered a general item.
Specific vs. General Items in Customs Tariff
As such, pot motors should be assessed under the specific provisions of Item 72(3) rather than the more general provisions of Item 73(21).
Requirement for Reasoned Orders in Quasi-Judicial Proceedings
Authorities exercising quasi-judicial functions must provide clear and articulate reasons for their decisions to ensure transparency and fairness.
Requirement for Reasoned Orders in Quasi-Judicial Proceedings
The failure to provide reasons for decisions is a disregard for the legal requirement and undermines the credibility of the adjudicatory process.
Principle of Natural Justice in Administrative Law
The principle of audi alteram partem, which mandates that a fair hearing be given, is fundamental to ensuring that administrative authorities and tribunals adhere to natural justice.
Principle of Natural Justice in Administrative Law
In the case at hand, the lack of sufficient reasoning in the orders issued by the Assistant Collector, Collector, and Government of India raises concerns about the compliance with this principle.
Need for Independent Quasi-Judicial Tribunals
There is a recommendation for the establishment of independent quasi-judicial tribunals to adjudicate disputes arising under customs and excise laws, akin to existing tribunals in other areas.
Need for Independent Quasi-Judicial Tribunals
Such independent bodies would enhance public confidence in the adjudicatory process and ensure that appeals and revisions are handled with greater fairness and rigor.
1587815: Contributory Negligence of Minors

A very young child, such as an eight-year-old, cannot be found guilty of contributory negligence unless it can be shown that they had the maturity and understanding to take precaution for their own safety.
Contributory Negligence of Minors
The assessment of contributory negligence must consider the child's age, mental development, and the specific circumstances of the case.
Standard of Care for Children
The standard of care expected of a child differs from that of an adult; what constitutes negligence for an adult may not be applicable to a child.
Standard of Care for Children
Judges must evaluate a child's conduct based on their individual intelligence and experience in relation to their ability to perceive risks.
Assessment of Damages
Damages for personal injury must compensate for both past and future losses, including non-pecuniary damages such as pain, suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life.
Assessment of Damages
The assessment of damages should consider the victim's loss of capacity to engage in normal life activities and the impact on their future prospects.
Impact of Inflation on Damages
When assessing damages, the court should disregard future inflation in order to maintain a fair and reasonable compensation in the context of the time of the accident.
Impact of Inflation on Damages
Judgments should be made based on the economic conditions at the time of the injury rather than anticipated future economic changes.
Vicarious Liability

An employer is vicariously liable for the negligent actions of their employees, and in cases of accidents involving minors, the focus must be on the negligence of the driver rather than any alleged contributory negligence of the child.
Comprehensive Assessment of Loss
Compensation must encompass a comprehensive evaluation of all losses incurred by the injured party, reflecting the totality of their suffering and deprivation.
Comprehensive Assessment of Loss
The court's evaluation of damages should be guided by a sense of proportion, ensuring that awards are not excessively high or low relative to similar cases.
1262724: Application of Order 22 Rule 10 of the Civil Procedure Code
An application under Order 22 Rule 10 of the Civil Procedure Code is not sustainable if no application is made to the court where the suit is pending during the pendency of the suit.
Application of Order 22 Rule 10 of the Civil Procedure Code
The application cannot be sustained in the appellate court if the transfer in question occurred prior to the filing of the appeal.
Section 146 of the Civil Procedure Code allows a person claiming under another to initiate proceedings, including the right to continue an appeal.
The expression 'claiming under' is interpreted broadly to include cases of devolution and assignment, allowing a transferee to continue an appeal filed by the transferor.

The provisions of the Civil Procedure Code should be interpreted liberally, especially when they facilitate the exercise of rights by persons who have acquired those rights through devolution or assignment.
The court emphasized that the right to file an appeal inherently includes the right to continue an appeal initiated by the previous holder of that right.
Importance of Substantial Questions of Law
The court acknowledged that substantial questions of law arise in execution proceedings, particularly regarding the limitation of execution and the amount payable under a decree.
Importance of Substantial Questions of Law
The interests of a purchaser pendente lite are crucial, as they may be bound by the outcome of execution proceedings and must be given an opportunity to protect their rights.
363129: Presumptions Under Sections 118 and 139 of the Negotiable Instruments Act
Section 118 of the Negotiable Instruments Act establishes presumptions related to negotiable instruments, including that they are made for consideration.
Presumptions Under Sections 118 and 139 of the Negotiable Instruments Act
Section 139 of the Act provides that it shall be presumed, unless contrary is proved, that the holder of a cheque received it for the discharge of a debt or liability.
Burden of Proof and Rebuttal of Presumptions
The burden of proof shifts to the accused once the execution of the negotiable instrument is proved or admitted.
Burden of Proof and Rebuttal of Presumptions
To rebut the presumptions under Sections 118 and 139, the accused is required to provide evidence that the cheque was not issued for consideration or for discharging a debt.
Nature of Evidence Required to Disprove Presumptions
The accused does not need to prove the non-existence of consideration and debt beyond a reasonable doubt, but must provide evidence that raises doubt about these presumptions.
Nature of Evidence Required to Disprove Presumptions
Circumstantial evidence or facts that compel the court to believe in the non-existence of consideration or debt may also be used to rebut the presumptions.
Judicial Authority in Sentencing Following Conviction
An Appellate Court, upon convicting an accused, must impose the appropriate sentence rather than remitting the matter to the trial court for sentencing.
Judicial Authority in Sentencing Following Conviction
The judicial discretion to impose a sentence cannot be delegated to another court once a conviction is established.
Assessment of Transactions and Liabilities
The lack of corroborative evidence, such as account books or delivery acknowledgments, can lead to reasonable doubt regarding the existence of a transaction.
Assessment of Transactions and Liabilities
If the evidence suggests that no sale took place, the presumption of a debt or liability being discharged by the cheque becomes questionable.
583374: Standard of Review for Appellate Courts
An appellate court should not interfere with a trial court's acquittal unless the trial court's conclusion is perverse or not based on any material evidence.
Standard of Review for Appellate Courts
If the trial court's view is reasonable and plausible, it should not be reversed merely because another conclusion is possible.
Minor inconsistencies in eyewitness accounts do not necessarily discredit their testimony, especially when they are injuries sustained by the witnesses.
It is not necessary for all eyewitnesses to describe the distinct acts of each member of an unlawful assembly.
Presence of Enmity and Its Impact on Testimony
Previous enmity between the parties does not automatically discredit clear evidence from eyewitnesses, particularly when the prosecution establishes the context of the attack.
Definition and Application of Unlawful Assembly
Section 149 of the IPC applies when an offence is committed in the prosecution of the common object of an unlawful assembly, regardless of whether all members actively participated.
Definition and Application of Unlawful Assembly
The requirement for a minimum of five persons to constitute an unlawful assembly does not negate the conviction of fewer individuals if they are found guilty of participating in the common object.

Judicial precedent clarifies that the absence of independent witnesses does not necessarily undermine the credibility of eyewitnesses, particularly when their testimony is corroborated by the circumstances of the case.
Burden of Proof in Appeals Against Acquittal
In appeals against acquittal, the burden lies on the prosecution to demonstrate that the trial court's findings were unreasonable or erroneous.
1489350: Nature of Termination Order
The holding of a preliminary inquiry does not alter the character of a termination order for a temporary government servant.
Nature of Termination Order
A temporary employee has no right to hold the post, and their services may be terminated without assigning any reason under the terms of their contract.
Application of 'Last Come First Go' Principle
The principle of 'last come first go' applies primarily in cases of retrenchment due to reduction in work or cadre shrinkage.
Application of 'Last Come First Go' Principle
This principle does not apply when terminating services based on the assessment of work and suitability of temporary employees.
Adverse Remarks and Preliminary Inquiry
Adverse remarks made against a temporary employee can form a valid basis for termination.
Adverse Remarks and Preliminary Inquiry
A preliminary inquiry may be conducted to assess the suitability of a temporary employee for continued service, but it does not necessitate a formal disciplinary inquiry.
Distinction Between Types of Inquiry
A preliminary inquiry is intended to collect facts regarding a temporary employee's conduct and is not punitive in nature.
Distinction Between Types of Inquiry
Only a formal departmental inquiry with charges framed necessitates the protections provided under Article 311(2) of the Constitution.
Right to Opportunity in Inquiry
Temporary government servants do not have a right to be heard during preliminary inquiries, as these are not meant for punitive action.
Right to Opportunity in Inquiry
If a preliminary inquiry leads to termination, it does not equate to dismissal or punishment if it is conducted within the framework of the contract of service.
Assessment of Work and Conduct
The competent authority is entitled to terminate a temporary employee based on their work and conduct assessment, even if junior employees are retained.
Assessment of Work and Conduct
Such decisions must align with the terms and conditions of service and do not necessarily violate constitutional equality principles.
110552: Applicability of Part I of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act

Part I of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act applies to arbitrations held in India and to international commercial arbitrations held outside India unless expressly or impliedly excluded by the parties.
Applicability of Part I of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act
Section 2(2) does not state that Part I shall not apply to arbitrations taking place outside India, indicating the legislature's intention for it to also apply in such cases.
Jurisdiction of Indian Courts
Indian courts retain jurisdiction to hear applications for interim measures in international commercial arbitrations, regardless of whether the arbitration is held in India or abroad.
Jurisdiction of Indian Courts
The definition of 'Court' under the Act does not restrict jurisdiction to arbitrations held within India.
Interpretation of Legislative Intent
The interpretation of statutes must align with the legislature's intent, which is to establish a uniform framework for international commercial arbitration.
Interpretation of Legislative Intent
An interpretation that leads to a lacuna in the law or leaves parties without remedies is generally to be avoided.
Interim Measures under Section 9
Section 9 permits applications for interim measures to be made to Indian courts before, during, or after arbitral proceedings, regardless of the arbitration's location.
Interim Measures under Section 9
The provisions of Section 9 can apply to arbitrations held outside India, provided the parties have not excluded its application.
Relationship between Part I and Part II of the Act
Part II of the Act deals with enforcement of foreign awards and does not contain provisions similar to those in Part I that govern interim measures.
Relationship between Part I and Part II of the Act
This indicates that the provisions in Part I are applicable to all arbitrations unless expressly excluded by agreement.
Role of ICC Rules in Interim Measures
Under ICC Rules, parties can apply for interim measures to judicial authorities, allowing for applications under Section 9 where ICC arbitration rules are applicable.
Role of ICC Rules in Interim Measures
This highlights the compatibility of the provisions of the Act with institutional arbitration rules.
594652: Negligence Defined
Negligence is categorized as either composite or contributory, with a focus on the omission of duty caused by either an act of omission or commission that leads to injury.
Negligence Defined
Negligence is defined as the failure to observe the necessary degree of care, precaution, and vigilance which the circumstances demand.
Contributory Negligence
Contributory negligence occurs when a plaintiff's own negligent actions contribute to their injury, which may limit the liability of other negligent parties.
Contributory Negligence
In cases of contributory negligence, courts have the discretion to apportion damages between the parties based on shared responsibility.
Doctrine of Last Opportunity
The doctrine of last opportunity holds that when both parties are negligent, the party who had the last opportunity to avoid the injury is liable.
Doctrine of Last Opportunity
This doctrine is not a strict rule of law but rather a test of causation.
Assessment of Compensation
In assessing compensation for death, both the age of the deceased and the claimants must be considered.
Assessment of Compensation
The multiplier method is the accepted approach for determining compensation, particularly in cases involving the death of a child.
Impact of Traffic Violations
Merely violating traffic regulations does not exempt a party from liability; evidence must establish the extent of each party's negligence.
Impact of Traffic Violations
The absence of clear evidence to establish sole responsibility for the accident does not absolve the corporation from liability.
Reduction of Compensation
Compensation may be reduced based on the degree of contributory negligence attributed to the victim, with reasonable deductions applied.
1198914: Insurer's Liability and Breach of Policy Conditions
The Tribunal cannot direct the insurer to pay compensation if it is exonerated from liability due to a fundamental breach of the insurance policy.
Insurer's Liability and Breach of Policy Conditions
The insurer's liability is strictly governed by the terms of the insurance policy and the statutory provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act.
Role of the Tribunal in Directing Compensation Payments
The Tribunal's power is limited by statutory provisions, and it cannot issue general directions to insurers to pay compensation when they are not liable.
Role of the Tribunal in Directing Compensation Payments
The directions given by the Tribunal to ensure timely compensation payments must align with the statutory framework and cannot contravene the established legal principles.
Interpretation of 'Third Party' under the Motor Vehicles Act
Gratuitous passengers or those not covered by the insurance policy cannot be classified as 'third parties' for the purposes of the Motor Vehicles Act.
Interpretation of 'Third Party' under the Motor Vehicles Act
The insurer is not liable to indemnify claims from individuals who do not have a direct contractual relationship with the insurance policy.
Extraordinary Jurisdiction of the Apex Court
Directions given by the Supreme Court in the exercise of extraordinary jurisdiction under Articles 136 and 142 of the Constitution are not binding precedents.
Extraordinary Jurisdiction of the Apex Court
While the Supreme Court may grant relief in specific cases, such directions should not be interpreted as establishing a general rule applicable in all similar situations.
Recovery Procedures for Insurers
In cases where the insurer is directed to pay compensation, it may later recover the payment from the owner of the vehicle without needing to file a separate suit.
Recovery Procedures for Insurers
